prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Yujin Mikotoba
Description: A medical professor at the Imperial Yumei University. He is an authority in forensic science in charge of the university's laboratory. He also happens to be my father.
Character 1
Name: Rei Membami
Description: An assistant to my father in his laboratory at the Imperial Yumei University. She's my best friend, and considers herself very much indebted to the late Dr John Wilson.
Character 2
Name: Jezaille Brett
Description: The victim of the case who was a former British exchange student. Nine months ago, she was found guilty of the murder of visiting professor Dr John Wilson.
Character 3
Name: Taketsuchi Auchi
Description: The lead prosecutor of this case, who appears to be struggling to accept the changes afoot as a result of these turbulent new times in Japan - the Meiji era.
Character 4
Name: Satoru Hosonaga
Description: A chief inspector in the Imperial Police Bureau who was surreptitiously submerged in the sea in order to keep watch over Miss Brett. He was present at the time of her murder.
Character 5
Name: Soseki Natsume
Description: A former visiting student to the British empire who returned to Japan after a spell of bad luck with the law. He's now a successful author and a witness in the current case.
Character 6
Name: Raiten Menimemo
Description: A journalist for the Shoyu News who's currently following Soseki-san everywhere, reporting on his every move. As a result, he's an eyewitness to the incident.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Post-Mortem Report
Description: Time of death just after 2 p.m. Death is believed to be due to trauma to the victim's lung from a knife blade. Only a single wound was identified.
Evidence 1
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the scene taken by police just after the incident occurred. The stab wound in the victim's back is clearly visible.
Evidence 2
Name: Soseki Natsume Article
Description: A newspaper containing an article about a discussion between my father and Soseki-san. The debate became quite spirited.
Evidence 3
Name: Fountain Pen
Description: The pen that the victim was found grasping in her hand. It carries the initials 'R.M.'. The fountain pen that the victim was found grasping in her hand. It carries the initials 'R.M.' as well as an emblem of some description. A fountain pen bearing the initials 'R.M.' and an emblem of some description. There is a very small amount of liquid still inside the ink reservoir.
Evidence 4
Name: Poison Article
Description: An article about poison that was stolen from a laboratory at Yumei University. Even my father, who is responsible for the lab, knew nothing of the incident. An article about poison that was stolen from a laboratory at Yumei University. The reporter, Menimemo-san, based it on information he gleaned by eavesdropping.
Evidence 5
Name: Incriminating Photograph
Description: A photographic print taken at the moment the victim was attacked. My friend Rei can be seen kneeling over Miss Brett.
Evidence 6
Name: Chemical Reagent
Description: A special indicator solution for a new poison under development by my father's team. It's been created in strict secrecy and exists only in my father's laboratory.
Evidence 7
Name: Murder Weapon
Description: A small knife from the scene of the crime that was found in the victim's back. No trace of poison was found on the blade.
Evidence 8
Name: Beach Hut Plan
Description: A plan of the layout of the small beach hut where the victim was found.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: On the day of the incident, I was ordered on a special surveillance assignment in this disguise.
Person: Hosonaga
Testimony 1
Testimony: I'd just managed to catch that crab when I suddenly heard a caterwaul from behind me.
Person: Soseki
Testimony 2
Testimony: I ran into the beach hut at once, where I found the pair in question.
Person: Hosonaga
Testimony 3
Testimony: YES YES YES! That young girl was astride the Englishwoman, dagger in hand, as she stabbed wildly!
Person: Soseki
Testimony 4
Testimony: I saw blood on the blade. It proved to me that she'd stabbed the victim multiple times.
Person: Hosonaga

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. First, I need to understand what's being asked. The task is to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. I have to look through all the provided characters, evidences, and testimonies to spot such a contradiction.

Starting with the evidences:

Evidence 0 (Post-Mortem Report) says the cause of death was a single knife wound to the lung, with only one wound. 

Evidence 7 (Murder Weapon) mentions that the knife found in the victim's back had no traces of poison. 

Evidence 1 (Crime Scene Photograph) shows the stab wound in the back. 

Evidence 5 (Incriminating Photograph) shows Rei kneeling over the victim with a dagger. 

Evidence 4 (Poison Article) talks about a stolen poison article related to the university. 

Now the testimonies:

Testimony 3 (from Soseki) claims that Rei was stabbing the victim multiple times with a dagger. 

Testimony 4 (from Hosonaga) mentions seeing blood on the blade, implying multiple stabs. 

But the Post-Mortem Report (Evidence 0) states only a single wound. So Testimony 3 and 4's mention of multiple stabs contradicts Evidence 0's single wound. 

Wait, but the question specifies only one pair. Let me check again. 

Testimony 4 says "stabbed multiple times" but the evidence says only one wound. That's a direct contradiction. 

Alternatively, Testimony 3 also says "stabbed wildly" which might imply multiple stabs. 

So the contradiction is between Evidence 0 (single wound) and Testimony 4 (multiple stabs). 

Wait, the user might expect the answer to be between Evidence 0 and Testimony 4. Let me confirm.

Yes, the Post-Mortem Report (Evidence 0) clearly states a single wound, while Testimony 4 claims multiple stabs. So that's the contradiction. 

Another possible contradiction: Evidence 7 says the knife had no poison, but if any testimony mentions poison, but I don't see that here. 

Looking at Testimony 0 and 1 don't seem relevant. 

So the correct pair would be Evidence 0 and Testimony 4.
</think>

cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let me start by going through each evidence and testimony carefully.

First, the characters involved here are Yujin Mikotoba (the professor and father of the narrator), Rei Membami (his assistant and friend), Jezaille Brett (the victim), Taketsuchi Auchi (prosecutor), Satoru Hosonaga (inspector), Soseki Natsume (author and witness), and Raiten Menimemo (journalist). The evidences provided are the post-mortem report, crime scene photo, Soseki's article, the fountain pen, poison article, incriminating photo, chemical reagent, murder weapon, and beach hut plan. The testimonies are from Hosonaga and others, focusing on medical knowledge, motive, and the defendant's actions.

Looking at the testimonies, Testimony 0 to 4 are all from Hosonaga. Let's parse each testimony:

Testimony 0: Hosonaga says pulling a blade from a wound could cause heavy bleeding, implying that if the defendant pulled the knife out, it would lead to more bleeding. Testimony 1 reinforces that this is basic medical knowledge, so the defendant (Rei) should know this. Testimony 2 states there's no reason why the defendant would try to pull the knife out. Testimony 3 and 4 talk about motive, but those are separate.

Now, looking at the evidence. Evidence 7 is the murder weapon: the knife found in the victim's back. The description says "no trace of poison was found on the blade." Wait, but that's about poison, not directly related to pulling the knife. Hmm, maybe not the right path.

Wait, the contradiction might be between the testimonies about the defendant not pulling the knife and the evidence of the knife's state. Wait, the post-mortem report (Evidence 0) says there was only a single wound. If the knife was left in, that's consistent with a single wound. But if Hosonaga is arguing that the defendant pulled it out (which would cause more bleeding), but the post-mortem only mentions a single wound, maybe the presence of the knife in the wound (Evidence 1's photo shows it there) suggests it wasn't pulled out. Wait, but Testimony 2 says there's no reason the defendant would pull it out, implying that if she did, it would be evidence against her. But the evidence shows the knife was still in the victim, so maybe that contradicts Hosonaga's implication that she did pull it out?

Wait, maybe I need to look again. The murder weapon (Evidence 7) is described as "found in the victim's back," so it was left there. The post-mortem (Evidence 0) says only a single wound. If Hosonaga is saying that pulling the knife would cause more bleeding, but the evidence shows only one wound, then perhaps the defendant didn't pull it out, contradicting the testimony's implication that she did? Or maybe the testimony is trying to argue that she did pull it out, which would cause more bleeding, but the evidence (only one wound) suggests she didn't, hence contradiction.

Alternatively, Testimony 2 says "there's no good reason why the defendant would have tried to pull the knife from the victim." But if the knife was found in the victim (Evidence 7), that means it wasn't pulled out. So Hosonaga's testimony is arguing that she had a motive and would do so, but the evidence shows she didn't, which would contradict. Wait, but Testimony 2 is saying there's no reason she would try to pull it out, but maybe the prosecutor is trying to say she did, but the evidence shows she didn't. Hmm, this is a bit confusing.

Wait, Testimony 0 and 1 are Hosonaga pointing out that pulling the knife would cause bleeding, implying that if Rei did it, that's a bad move. Testimony 2 says there's no reason she would do that. Wait, maybe the contradiction is in the testimonies themselves? Or perhaps the evidence that the knife was left in (so it wasn't pulled out) contradicts the testimony that she would have pulled it out? Wait, but the testimonies don't explicitly say she pulled it out. They're arguing that she had a motive and knowledge, but the evidence shows the knife was still there, so she didn't pull it out, which might contradict the idea that she did it. Hmm, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 2 (saying there's no reason she would pull it out) and the fact that the knife was indeed left in (so she didn't pull it, which aligns with Testimony 2's point). Wait, that would support, not contradict.

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between the post-mortem report (Evidence 0) stating only a single wound and Testimony 4's implication that the defendant had a motive. But motive doesn't contradict evidence of wound count. Not sure.

Looking again at the testimonies:

Testimony 3 and 4 are about motive. The contradiction might be elsewhere. Let me check Evidence 5: Incriminating Photograph shows Rei kneeling over Miss Brett. But Testimony 5 isn't here, but Testimony 3 from Soseki says he saw Rei stabbing, but Evidence 5's photo might show her in a different position. Wait, but in the current testimonies listed here, Testimonies 0-4 are from Hosonaga. The incriminating photo (Evidence 5) shows Rei kneeling, but maybe Testimony 3 from Soseki (if present) would say she was stabbing. Wait, in the provided testimonies, Testimony 3 is from Soseki saying he saw Rei astride with a dagger, stabbing multiple times. However, the post-mortem (Evidence 0) says only one wound. So that would be a contradiction between Testimony 3 (multiple stabs) and Evidence 0 (single wound). But in the current setup, the user's provided testimonies here are only Testimonies 0-4 from Hosonaga. Wait, looking back at the user's input, the Testimonies listed here are Testimony 0 to 4, all from Hosonaga except maybe Soseki? Let me check.

Wait in the Testimonies section provided by the user, the Testimonies are:

Testimony 0: Hosonaga  
Testimony 1: Hosonaga  
Testimony 2: Hosonaga  
Testimony 3: Soseki (since Testimony 3 says "YES YES YES! That young girl..." which matches Soseki's character description as a witness).  
Testimony 4: Hosonaga

Wait, the Testimonies listed by the user include Testimony 3 from Soseki. So Testimony 3 is from Soseki, stating that Rei was stabbing multiple times. The Post-Mortem Report (Evidence 0) says only a single wound. So that's a direct contradiction: Testimony 3 claims multiple stabs, but the evidence shows only one. Therefore, the pair would be Evidence 0 and Testimony 3.

But in the current problem, the user's latest input has the Testimonies as:

Testimonies:
Testimony 0: Hosonaga  
Testimony 1: Hosonaga  
Testimony 2: Hosonaga  
Testimony 3: Soseki (the one with "YES YES YES!")  
Testimony 4: Hosonaga  

So the contradiction between Evidence 0 (single wound) and Testimony 3 (multiple stabs) is a valid pair. However, the user's previous examples required choosing only one pair, and in the current problem's context, the user might be expecting this pair. But wait, the user's question here is about the current setup where the Testimonies provided are Testimony 0-4 (with Testimony 3 being Soseki's), and Evidence 0 and Testimony 3 contradict.

Alternatively, another possible contradiction: Evidence 7 (murder weapon found in the back, no poison) and Testimony 0-2 about pulling the knife. If Hosonaga argues that pulling the knife would cause bleeding, but the evidence shows the knife was left in (so not pulled out), then the testimony's implication that the defendant pulled it (leading to bleeding) is contradicted by the evidence that it wasn't pulled. However, Testimony 2 says "there's no good reason why the defendant would have tried to pull the knife from the victim." So Hosonaga is arguing that she wouldn't pull it, but maybe the evidence shows she didn't, which aligns with that testimony. Not a contradiction.

Alternatively, the Testimony 4 says the victim had murdered Dr. Wilson, who was the defendant's mentor. The defendant (Rei) would have a motive. But Evidence 2 is an article about a discussion between Yujin and Soseki, which might not relate directly. The poison article (Evidence 4) was stolen, but the murder weapon didn't have poison (Evidence 7). So maybe the poison article's theft (Evidence 4) and the weapon not having poison (Evidence7) could be related, but that's not a direct contradiction with a testimony here.

The strongest contradiction seems to be between Evidence 0 (single wound) and Testimony 3 (multiple stabs). So the answer should be {"evidence":0, "testimony":3}
</think>

cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let me start by going through each evidence and testimony carefully.

First, looking at the evidences:

Evidence 0 (Post-Mortem Report) states that the victim died from a single knife wound to the lung, and the time of death was just after 2 p.m. Only one wound was identified.

Evidence 1 (Crime Scene Photograph) shows the stab wound in the victim's back, which aligns with the post-mortem report's single wound.

Evidence 3 (Fountain Pen) mentions the pen found in the victim's hand with initials "R.M." and an emblem. The liquid inside might be relevant, but not sure yet.

Evidence 5 (Incriminating Photograph) shows Rei kneeling over the victim. This might indicate her involvement, but the testimony from Menimemo (Testimony 2) says the girl (Rei?) stabbed the victim. So maybe this supports the testimony, but need to check.

Evidence 7 (Murder Weapon) is the knife found in the victim's back, and it has no poison. So the death was from the knife wound, not poison.

Now the testimonies from Menimemo:

Testimony 0: He observed through gaps in the reed screens.

Testimony 1: The victim was sitting on a stool when the girl (Rei?) entered and argued.

Testimony 2: The girl pulled out a knife, threw the victim to the floor, and stabbed her in the back. This implies a single stabbing, which matches the post-mortem report. Wait, but maybe the contradiction is elsewhere.

Testimony 3 and 4: He took photos without entering, using the reed gaps. The Incriminating Photograph (Evidence 5) was taken at the moment of attack, showing Rei kneeling. If Menimemo took the photo without entering, how does the photo show the attacker? Maybe the photo was taken from outside through the gaps? The description of Evidence 5 says it was taken at the moment of attack, so maybe that's possible. Not a contradiction yet.

Testimony 5: He never set foot in the hut, only observed. That aligns with Testimony 4.

Wait, looking at Testimony 2 says the girl stabbed her in the back. The Post-Mortem (Evidence 0) says the wound was in the lung from a back stab, which matches. So that's consistent.

Hmm. Let me check other testimonies. The prosecutor's testimonies (Hosonaga) might also have contradictions, but the question is about Menimemo's testimonies and the evidences provided.

Wait, Evidence 5 is the Incriminating Photograph which shows Rei kneeling over the victim. Menimemo's testimony (Testimony 4) says he took the photo by poking the camera through the reed screen. If the photo (Evidence 5) is that photo, then it's possible. But maybe there's another contradiction.

Wait, Testimony 2 says the girl stabbed the victim in the back, which aligns with the post-mortem. But maybe the contradiction is between the number of wounds? The post-mortem says only one wound, so if Menimemo's testimony says she stabbed once, that's okay. But perhaps another point.

Looking at Evidence 7 (Murder Weapon) says the knife had no poison. If any testimony claimed poison was used, that would conflict. But Menimemo's testimony doesn't mention poison, so maybe that's not it.

Wait, looking at Testimony 3 from Menimemo: He mentions taking the photo by poking the lens through the screen. The Incriminating Photograph (Evidence 5) was taken at the moment of the attack. So that's possible. Not a contradiction.

Wait, maybe Evidence 5's description says Rei is seen kneeling over the victim. But Testimony 2 says the girl (Rei) stabbed her in the back. If the photo shows her kneeling after the stabbing, that's consistent. Maybe no contradiction here.

Hmm, perhaps I'm missing something. Let me check all evidence and testimonies again.

Looking at Evidence 3: The fountain pen with R.M. initials. Menimemo's name is Raiten Menimemo, so R.M. could be his initials. If the pen was in the victim's hand, maybe suggesting she had it, but Menimemo's testimony doesn't mention that. Not sure yet.

Wait, Testimony 5 says Menimemo never entered the hut. But the fountain pen (Evidence 3) is in the victim's hand. If Menimemo's initials are on the pen, maybe he touched it, but he claims he didn't enter. That could be a contradiction. Let me check:

Evidence 3's description says the pen has initials "R.M." which could be Raiten Menimemo. If the victim was holding his pen, but Menimemo never entered the hut (Testimony 5), then how did the pen get there? Unless he left it there earlier, but that's possible. Maybe not a direct contradiction, but possible.

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 2 says the girl stabbed her in the back, leading to the single wound, which matches the post-mortem. So no contradiction there.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 5 and Testimony 4. Testimony 4 says he took the photo by poking the lens through the screen. If the photo (Evidence 5) shows Rei kneeling over the victim, then that would require the camera to be positioned in a way that can capture that angle through the gaps. If the reed screens' gaps didn't allow such a clear view, then that's a contradiction. But the description of Evidence 5 just says it was taken at the moment, so maybe it's possible.

Hmm, maybe I'm overcomplicating. Let's see other possibilities.

Looking at Evidence 0's time of death: 2 p.m. Any testimony conflicting with that? Menimemo's testimonies don't mention time, so not there.

Wait, Testimony 1 says the victim was sitting on a stool when the girl entered. If the post-mortem time is 2 p.m., and Menimemo's account of the events leading up to that are consistent, then no conflict.

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 7 (no poison on the blade) and some testimony mentioning poison. But Menimemo's testimonies don't mention poison. The Poison Article (Evidence 4) is about stolen poison, but that's from the university. Maybe another character's testimony, but the user hasn't provided others here.

Wait, the user provided all testimonies from Menimemo here. Let me check again the Testimonies section.

The Testimonies listed here are all from Menimemo (Character 6). So the only testimonies to consider are Testimonies 0-5 from him.

So focusing on those:

Testimony 2 says the girl stabbed the victim in the back. The post-mortem (Evidence 0) confirms a single back wound, so that's consistent.

Testimony 5 says Menimemo never entered the hut. If the pen (Evidence 3) has his initials and was found in the victim's hand, but he didn't enter, that might imply someone else put it there, but not a direct contradiction unless he admits to having it. Since the pen is in the victim's hand, maybe she took it from him earlier, but he didn't enter during the incident. Not sure if that's a contradiction.

Alternatively, Evidence 5's photo shows Rei kneeling over the victim. If Menimemo took that photo (as per Testimony 4), then that's possible through the screen. So not a contradiction.

Wait, perhaps Testimony 2 says the girl "stabbed her in the back", but the post-mortem says the wound caused lung trauma from a back stab. That matches, so no contradiction there.

Hmm, maybe I'm missing something obvious. Let's check the Evidence 5 again. It says "taken at the moment the victim was attacked" and shows Rei kneeling. If Menimemo's Testimony 2 says the girl (Rei) stabbed her, then the photo supports that. Not a contradiction.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 7 (no poison on the blade) and Testimony 4? No, Testimony 4 doesn't mention poison.

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 6 (Chemical Reagent) which is a poison reagent from the lab. If any testimony linked Rei to using poison, but Menimemo's testimonies don't mention that. So maybe not.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Evidence 0 (single wound) and Testimony 2, which says she "stabbed her in the back" (singular), so that's consistent. So no contradiction here.

Hmm, maybe I need to think differently. Let's look for any other possible contradictions.

Looking at Evidence 5's description: "taken at the moment the victim was attacked. Rei can be seen kneeling over Miss Brett." prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Yujin Mikotoba
Description: A medical professor at the Imperial Yumei University. He is an authority in forensic science in charge of the university's laboratory. He also happens to be my father.
Character 1
Name: Rei Membami
Description: An assistant to my father in his laboratory at the Imperial Yumei University. She's my best friend, and considers herself very much indebted to the late Dr John Wilson.
Character 2
Name: Jezaille Brett
Description: The victim of the case who was a former British exchange student. Nine months ago, she was found guilty of the murder of visiting professor Dr John Wilson.
Character 3
Name: Taketsuchi Auchi
Description: The lead prosecutor of this case, who appears to be struggling to accept the changes afoot as a result of these turbulent new times in Japan - the Meiji era.
Character 4
Name: Satoru Hosonaga
Description: A chief inspector in the Imperial Police Bureau who was surreptitiously submerged in the sea in order to keep watch over Miss Brett. He was present at the time of her murder.
Character 5
Name: Soseki Natsume
Description: A former visiting student to the British empire who returned to Japan after a spell of bad luck with the law. He's now a successful author and a witness in the current case.
Character 6
Name: Raiten Menimemo
Description: A journalist for the Shoyu News who's currently following Soseki-san everywhere, reporting on his every move. As a result, he's an eyewitness to the incident.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Post-Mortem Report
Description: Time of death just after 2 p.m. Death is believed to be due to trauma to the victim's lung from a knife blade. Only a single wound was identified.
Evidence 1
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the scene taken by police just after the incident occurred. The stab wound in the victim's back is clearly visible.
Evidence 2
Name: Soseki Natsume Article
Description: A newspaper containing an article about a discussion between my father and Soseki-san. The debate became quite spirited.
Evidence 3
Name: Fountain Pen
Description: The pen that the victim was found grasping in her hand. It carries the initials 'R.M.'. The fountain pen that the victim was found grasping in her hand. It carries the initials 'R.M.' as well as an emblem of some description. A fountain pen bearing the initials 'R.M.' and an emblem of some description. There is a very small amount of liquid still inside the ink reservoir.
Evidence 4
Name: Poison Article
Description: An article about poison that was stolen from a laboratory at Yumei University. Even my father, who is responsible for the lab, knew nothing of the incident. An article about poison that was stolen from a laboratory at Yumei University. The reporter, Menimemo-san, based it on information he gleaned by eavesdropping.
Evidence 5
Name: Incriminating Photograph
Description: A photographic print taken at the moment the victim was attacked. My friend Rei can be seen kneeling over Miss Brett.
Evidence 6
Name: Chemical Reagent
Description: A special indicator solution for a new poison under development by my father's team. It's been created in strict secrecy and exists only in my father's laboratory.
Evidence 7
Name: Murder Weapon
Description: A small knife from the scene of the crime that was found in the victim's back. No trace of poison was found on the blade.
Evidence 8
Name: Beach Hut Plan
Description: A plan of the layout of the small beach hut where the victim was found.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Oh yes, I stabbed the Englishwoman. And it's that very fact that proves I'm innocent!
Person: Menimemo
Testimony 1
Testimony: Because why would I have bothered to stab the woman if I'd already poisoned her?
Person: Menimemo
Testimony 2
Testimony: When I heard the student girl and that pompous English murderer arguing...it got my goat.
Person: Menimemo
Testimony 3
Testimony: It was nothing to do with Dr Wilson! We were discussing the stolen poison.
Person: Rei
Testimony 4
Testimony: If the courts weren't going to punish Brett for what she did, someone else would have to see justice done!
Person: Menimemo
Testimony 5
Testimony: The point is...if you'd poisoned someone, there'd be no reason to then go and stab the person as well!
Person: Menimemo

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. The user provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies, and I have to pick one pair where they don't align.

First, I'll go through each evidence and see what it states, then check the testimonies to find any conflicting statements.

Looking at Evidence 7: Murder Weapon. The description says it's a small knife found in the victim's back, and **no trace of poison was found on the blade**. 

Now, looking at Testimonies by Menimemo (Testimony 0 and 1, 5):

Testimony 5: "If you'd poisoned someone, there'd be no reason to then go and stab the person as well!" 

Menimemo's defense is that he used both methods (poison and stabbing), but his point is that using both doesn't make sense. However, the murder weapon's lack of poison might not directly contradict his testimony. 

Wait, Testimony 5 says "if you poisoned, no need to stab" so Menimemo is arguing that since he stabbed, he didn't poison. But Evidence 7 shows that the knife has no poison, so that aligns with his testimony. Hmm, maybe not. 

Wait another angle: Evidence 3 is the Fountain Pen with R.M. initials (Menimemo's initials). If the pen was in the victim's hand, maybe that places Menimemo at the scene. But how does that contradict a testimony? Testimony 5 says he didn't poison, but maybe the pen has something to do with the poison? Not sure.

Wait, looking at Testimony 3 by Rei: "We were discussing the stolen poison." So the debate was about the stolen poison, which Menimemo's article was based on. If Menimemo stole the poison, then maybe he used it, but the murder weapon shows no poison. But the victim's death was from the knife. So if Menimemo poisoned her, but the poison wasn't on the knife, perhaps the poison wasn't the cause of death. The Post-Mortem (Evidence 0) says death was from the knife wound. So Menimemo's testimony that he stabbed her (Testimony 0) aligns with the cause of death. But his argument that he didn't poison because he stabbed is okay, unless there's evidence he did poison. 

Alternatively, if the poison was used but not via the knife, maybe through another method, but the post-mortem didn't find poison. So if Menimemo claims he used poison, but evidence shows no poison in the body, that would be a contradiction. However, the Post-Mortem doesn't mention poison, only the knife wound. The Chemical Reagent (Evidence 6) is the poison under development. If the poison was used but not detected, maybe due to the type, but the testimony says he didn't use it because he stabbed. 

Hmm, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 0 (Menimemo admitting to stabbing) and Evidence 3 (the pen with his initials was in the victim's hand). If the pen was his, and he was holding it when he stabbed, but the evidence shows the pen was in her hand, maybe that's a contradiction? Or maybe not, since he could have left it there. 

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 3 by Rei: "We were discussing the stolen poison." So the argument between Menimemo and the student (Rei?) was about the stolen poison. If Menimemo stole the poison (as per Evidence 4's article), then maybe he intended to use it but didn't, so the contradiction is that he claims he stabbed, but the poison was involved somehow. But the evidence doesn't show poison as the cause, so maybe that's okay. 

Wait, Testimony 5 says "if you poisoned, no need to stab," so Menimemo is arguing that since he stabbed, he didn't poison. But the evidence of the poison's theft (Evidence 4) and the chemical reagent (Evidence 6) might suggest he had access, but the murder weapon's lack of poison supports his claim. So maybe no contradiction there. 

Wait, maybe Evidence 5: Incriminating Photograph shows Rei kneeling over the victim. If Menimemo is the one who stabbed, but the photo shows Rei, that's a contradiction. But Testimony 0 says Menimemo did it. So Evidence 5 and Testimony 0 would contradict. But the user says only one pair, and I need to choose the best one. 

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 4 by Menimemo: "The point is...if you'd poisoned someone, there'd be no reason to then go and stab the person as well!" So he's saying using both methods is illogical, hence he only stabbed. But Evidence 7's knife has no poison, so if he used poison, it's not on the knife. But the post-mortem says death was from the knife, so poison wasn't the cause. So maybe no contradiction. 

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 0 (Menimemo admits to stabbing) and Evidence 3 (the pen with his initials in victim's hand). If he stabbed her, maybe the pen was his, so that's consistent. Not a contradiction. 

Hmm, perhaps the contradiction is between Evidence 4 (the poison article was based on Menimemo's eavesdropping) and Testimony where he says he didn't poison her. But that's not a direct contradiction.

But he claims he stabbed her because of the stolen poison (Testimony 2 mentions discussing the stolen poison led to the argument). However, the murder weapon's lack of poison doesn't contradict his motive, just the method. 

Alternatively, Evidence 7 says no poison on the blade, but if Menimemo used poison another way (like in drink), then the knife's lack of poison isn't a contradiction. 

Wait, maybe I missed something. Let me recheck:

The user asks for one pair. Let me see other possibilities.

Evidence 3: Fountain Pen with R.M. (Menimemo's initials) in victim's hand. If Menimemo was holding the pen when he stabbed, but the pen was in her hand, maybe that's a clue. Testimony 5 says he didn't poison, but the pen could be his, placing him there. Not a contradiction in itself, but maybe Testimony 5's logic about not needing to stab if poisoned vs the evidence that the death was by stabbing (so stabbing was necessary, hence no contradiction).

Alternatively, Testimony 0 says Menimemo stabbed, but Evidence 5's photo shows Rei doing it. That's a direct contradiction. Evidence 5 (photo of Rei) vs Testimony 0 (Menimemo admits). So the pair would be Evidence 5 and Testimony 0. But the user might have another angle.

Testimony 3 is by Rei: "It was nothing to do with Dr Wilson! We were discussing the stolen poison." So the argument was about stolen poison. Menimemo's Testimony 2 says they were arguing about the stolen poison. So that's consistent. 

Testimony 5: "The point is...if you poisoned someone, there'd be no reason to then go and stab the person as well!" So Menimemo is arguing that using both is illogical, hence he only stabbed. The evidence of the knife's lack of poison supports that he didn't poison.

Evidence 3: The fountain pen with R.M. (Menimemo's initials) was in the victim's hand. Alternatively, Testimony 3 by Rei says the argument was about the stolen poison, but if Menimemo used the poison and stabbed, that's conflicting with his own logic. But he says he didn't poison. 

Wait, the key might be in Testimony 5 where Menimemo argues that stabbing would be unnecessary if you poisoned. Since the evidence shows the murder weapon (knife) was used, and no poison on it, that supports his claim that he didn't poison. So no contradiction there. 

Hmm, perhaps the contradiction is between Evidence 3 (the pen with his initials) and Testimony 5 where he says he didn't poison. The pen being his doesn't directly relate to the poison, so maybe not. 

Wait, maybe Evidence 4 says the poison article was based on Menimemo's eavesdropping. If he stole the poison, that's one thing, but the murder weapon's lack of poison would mean he didn't use it, so that's okay. 

I'm a bit stuck. Let me try another approach.

Looking at Testimony 5: Menimemo says "if you poisoned, no need to stab". So he's saying he didn't poison. The evidence that supports this is the knife having no poison (Evidence 7). So that aligns. 

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Evidence 4 (the poison article was stolen from the lab) and Testimony where Menimemo didn't poison, so he stole the poison but didn't use it. Not a contradiction. 

Alternatively, Testimony 3 by Rei says the argument was about stolen poison, and Menimemo's Testimony 2 says they were arguing about that, so that's consistent.

Wait, maybe I'm missing something obvious. Let's see the testimonies again:

Testimony 0: Menimemo admits to stabbing the victim.

Testimony 5: He argues that using both poison and stabbing is illogical, so he only stabbed.

Evidence 7 says the knife has no poison. So that aligns. 

Evidence 5 shows Rei as the one stabbing, which contradicts Menimemo's admission. So that's the contradiction.
